sentence.idiomatic: Your child just doesn't get it; today I am going to teach him a good lesson.
He always arrives late for work. The boss often reprimands him.
You must remember this lesson. Hereafter, don't be like this.
He went out of town to handle some affairs and won't be able to get back for a couple of days.
He works very diligently. If you have something that needs to be done, feel free to give it to him to do.
It's such a small thing and you did it so poorly. You are too incompetent.
I also want to go to Paris. It's just a pity I don't have any time.
It's too bad I'm not by your side; otherwise I would certainly help you.
That clothing looks great. It's just too bad I'm so fat; I can't fit into it.
He doesn't understand the rules. You need to teach him a good lesson.
Since you have come here to do it, you need to understand the customs here.
This child has no manners; he always interrupts the adults when they are speaking.
I really regret not listening to you at the time.
I have absolutely no regrets over things that are already decided.
If you marry someone you don't like, you will definitely regret it.
That Peter... I really have to teach him a lesson. Hello? I need your help. There's a Canadian I don't ever want to see again. You get my drift?
I get it. We ninjas will take care of it. Relax.
Then I'll wait for the good news.
Hello, Peter.
Ah, Mr. Li. Have you shipped yet?
We'll ship next week.
Oh, please be a little faster.
I can be fast. Too bad you won't be around to see it.
Why not? What's that supposed to mean?
Peter, you don't understand the rules. Don't you think so?
I don't know what you mean. I didn't do anything wrong.
Ah, you still don't get it, do you? You're going to regret that.
I'm not afraid of you. Hello? Augh! Ninjas!
